snippet: The 20,000 fighters and others lost last year cast further doubt on Afghanistan’s ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.
abstract: Rapid rate of decline in Afghan Army personnel due to desertions, discharges or combat deaths raises concern about country's ability to maintain security absent coalition forces; Obama administration considers slowing withdrawal of American troops as newly available statistics underscore challenge of preparing Afghans to fight Taliban on their own.

byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED
byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg reported from Washington, and Azam Ahmed from Kabul, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: The 20,000 fighters and others lost last year cast further doubt on Afghanistan’s ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.

headline.main: Figures From U.S.-Led Coalition Show Heavy 2014 Losses for Afghan Army
headline.print_headline: Figures From U.S.-Led Coalition Show Heavy 2014 Losses for Afghan Army
